qas.question: Time has long been a major point of study in which fields?
Fields such as business, industry, sports, science, and performing arts incorporate some notion of what into their measuring systems?
What is an example of a simple definition of time?
Which three fields usually support performing arts?
What fields use measuring systems to check the weight of their products?
What does having rules in sports usually prevent?
What does science use to test a hypothesis?
What do athletes need to use to be aware of where their teammates are in a game?
Fields such as business, industry, sports, science, and performing arts incorporate some notion of what into their clocks?
What keeps everything from happening at different times?
What fields incorporate some notion of clocks into their measuring system?
What has long been a major subject of study in human sensation?

context: <b11_0>Time<b11_0/> has long been a major subject of study in <a0_0><b3_0>religion, philosophy, and science<b3_0/><a0_0/>, but defining it in a manner applicable to all fields without circularity has consistently eluded scholars. Nevertheless, diverse fields such as <b4_0><b10_0>business, industry<b4_0/>, sports, the sciences<b10_0/>, and the performing arts all incorporate some notion of <a1_0><b8_0>time<b8_0/><a1_0/> into their respective measuring systems. Some simple definitions of time include "<a2_0>time is what <b12_0>clocks<b12_0/> measure<a2_0/>", which is a problematically vague and self-referential definition that utilizes the device used to measure the subject as the definition of the subject, and "<b9_0>time<b9_0/> is what keeps <b5_0>everything from happening at once<b5_0/>", which is without substantive meaning in the absence of the definition of simultaneity in the context of the limitations of human sensation, <b6_0>observation<b6_0/> of events, and the <b7_0>perception<b7_0/> of such events.
